content.description: Updated to "White Dike, V1hb", per info from Bob Horan's new guidebook. Start on a big, two handed sloper, move up to and then past the horizontal crack using nice features, and make a couple more difficult moves to get to the top. I think the crux is going from a nice rounded hold up to the big, topout jug.
content.protection: Pads if you have them, but it is reasonably safe to go without.
content.location: This is the most obvious line in the dead center of the wall. See the photo.

climbs.name: Jenn's Folly
climbs.fa: unknown to this poster (no way this hasn't been climbed before)

content.description: Start at the far left side of the Dome Boulder. Work your way up the first crack sequence (above the obvious traverse). Your feet will end up in the traverse hand holds. The holds are relatively small - footwork is essential. Use the vertical crack left of the "Center Crack" route up & over the top. Use care on the last sequence (climbing out of the vertical crack) as a fall here could potentially break an ankle. Pads would be wise. A toprope could easily be set up if desired.
content.protection: One could build an anchor for a toprope if desired.

climbs.name: Dome Boulder Traverse
climbs.fa: someone before I was born? '50s maybe?

content.description: This is one of the most obvious problems here.  It turns out to be harder than it looks.  There are lots of jugs, but sometimes tricky moves are required between them.  A round trip on this can provide a pump (if you don't milk the good rests too long).
content.protection: There is a nice, flat, sandy landing under most of it....
content.location: Start on the left or right.
